The bug tracker requires setting up an account, and I believe that's separate from the forums.

Note that the bug tracker has been publicly available to players pretty much since forever, and the logging of feedback items has been available there, too.

There's nothing wrong with players logging feedback suggestions, there-- but it's not exactly a replacement for the Suggestions forum here, either.  If you're a player, and you log a feedback item, then that may make it somewhat more visible to the Squad folks than items here-- but, by the same token, you'll make it a lot less visible to the player base, since most forum users are not in the habit of routinely scanning the bug tracker for items to upvote or comment on.

My observation has been that the player suggestions most likely to get traction from Squad are the ones that have a lot of players behind them-- and you may have more luck with a forum thread, if you're trying to build popular support.

I think it all comes down to where people spend most of their time.  Forum users spend more time reading the forums than looking at the bug tracker.  I would guess that for most Squad folks, it would be the other way around.  So when someone has an idea, it's up to them to decide which venue they think would be the most effective vehicle for getting their point across.

(Nor does it necessarily have to be an either-or kind of scenario-- it's always possible to start a thread here, then make a feedback item that links to it and vice versa.)

This suggestions forum and the bug-tracker are very different contexts. 

+ This forum is a rather friendly (especially as internet forums go) place to talk about a suggestion and clarify what people want.

+ The bug-tracker is a more procedural environment to log definite suggestions in a way that can be rigorously tested by QA.  One dev who reads the forums says devs don't read the tracker, and we often to run into frustration typical of corporate processes.

The top vote-getting suggestions on the tracker are rather straightforward changes.   The top vote-getters are mostly those that got attention since the voting method was announced about six months ago, in which time some have been implemented.
20745 Make 1.25m parts have consistent mating-face diameters 
17912 Unlock Personal Parachutes with a Building Upgrade (instead of Kerbal Experience)
21006 Add "Warp to maneuver" button (in flight-view as well) [done for map-view in 1.7]
21314 Add a 1.25m Engine Plate
17928 Buff Mk2 Lander Can to compete with the new Mk1-3 Pod [done]
19076 Adjust some M.H. engine specs to balance better with other KSP engines [done]
17875 Adjust colliders on stack-separators/decouplers to match their visible shape
17286 Solution for the Click-Through problem (working example linked)

I think the best way to make use of both the Suggestions subforum and the official bugtracker is a two-pronged approach:

  • Use the Suggestions subforum to pitch your ideas, discuss it with fellow users and hash out the details
  • After a while, submit the idea as feedback on the official bugtracker, containing a summary/consensus of what was discussed in the forums
